NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for whom grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I find that our flags from Coqualeetza are too badly worn to be used on the new school. I would like to have a suitable flag for the main flag pole, a Union Jack, and would greatly appreciate it if the Department would furnish it.

There is a great deal of resonance in the Assembly Hall and even allowing for improvement upon the installing of benches and when the pupils would be in their places, I am quite sure that something extra will have to be done to insure good hearing upon the part of those in the pews. Consequently if we could have six or eight smaller flags, say 2'x3', or thereabouts, Union Jacks and Red Ensigns, these could be arranged in a way that would be both decorative and of assistance in securing better acoustics.

I might say also that we have no picture of the King and Queen, and if one could be secured for use in our Assembly Hall I would appreciate it as I intend to support heartily, the efforts of educational authorities to secure intelligent and loyal support of our authorities and institutions.

Trusting you may see your way clear to recommending this contribution I am,

Yours sincerely,

R.C Scott

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I would like also if you could give consideration to our application for a new office typewriter. The present one has been in use for many years. Under the ever increasing amount of work which has been laid upon our office, not alone through the approaching change in the location of the school, but also because of our endeavour to keep in touch with parents and friends through circular letters, and also largely through the great amount of detail made necessary in connection with our Preventorium, this old machine has been constantly in the hands of the repair man. I trust that it may be possible to secure a good machine, and would be grateful if you could see your way clear to recommend its purchase.

Department of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.

Dear Sirs:

In endeavouring to acquaint the young Indians of this School with something of a knowledge of the country in which they live, we find it quite impossible to proceed any further without at least two large size maps of Canada, which would be suitable to put on rollers for classroom instruction.

The only map now available in the School was acquired in 1930 and although it is slowly coming apart, it is still being used by both the intermediate and senior classes.

Hoping you will be able to supply us with these maps in the very near future, I remain,

Yours most sincerely,

Allen Raymer Reesor

CARDINAL WINS TWO CUPS IN S.D.H.S.P.A.

"CLOVERTIME", JUNIOR PLAY TO BE GIVEN NEXT FRIDAY

"CLOVERTIME" REHEARSAL IS A DAILY PROJECT FOR PRESENTATION BY Evelyn Lessman

Come! See! and hear! "Clovertime", junior class play which is to be presented at the Legion Hall, November 6. The play casts its daily working on parts and plans to give the audience satisfaction.

"If you want this play to be a success, do it right," remarks the director. She immediately receives correct response from the students, who are probably growing somewhat weary of it all, but just the same are anxiously waiting for the exciting night.

Don't forget at 8:15 Friday evening. The admission prices are ten, fifteen and twenty-five cents.

O. A. SHAFFER TO HEAD NOVEMBER PTA PROGRAM

"A Parent Looks at Homework" is the topic for the discussion of the next PTA (Cont. on P. 2 Col. 1)

SIXTEEN STUDENTS HAVE ENTERED LOCAL DECLAMATORY CONTEST

The declamatory contest has been pushed ahead to Friday evening, November 12, for the entrants here. The date planned was pushed ahead because it interfered with activities of the grades at the Legion Hall. Several students have re-entered the contest since the date has been changed. There are now sixteen in the "declam". In the poetical division are Leatrice Saloath, Ardyce Haggard and E. (Cont. on P. 3 Col. 2)

ORS CUP IS WON FOR THE CARDINAL, OTHER FOR ATTENDANCE

At the Brookings S.D.H.S.P.A Wentworth received two cups. One for winning first again this year on "The Cardinal" and the other for having the largest delegation there.

Capt. C. D. Martin led the round table discussion in the Ditto division in the afternoon.

Twelve awards were given for the different divisions in poems and annuals. The programs for the day included speeches in the forenoon, a business meeting in the afternoon and a pep meeting at night.

Gordon McNamara, S.D.H.S.P.A., president and Mr. K. S. Happen, Advisor, welcomed the high schools to the college and Mr. Charles Mitchell invited them to Brookings at the beginning (Cont. on P. 2 Col. 1)

Memorandum

The undersigned begs to submit herewith a letter from the Rev. Andrew T.B. Baird, of the 31st ultimo, suggesting that an Industrial Indian Day School be established in the West Coast Agency of Vancouver Island, the foundation for which he says has been laid by a Mr. John A. Donaldson, who has taken a number of Indian lads into his house for the purpose of teaching them, in which work Mr. Baird states.

To the Honourable
C.T. D'Arcy
Surgeon General of Indian Affairs
states that Mr. Donald enjoys the cordial cooperation and support of the local Indian Agent, Mr. A. Pullen; and he asks that the Department will agree to give a grant such as has been given to other similar institutions in British Columbia, for the establishment of an Industrial Board School among the Indians on the West coast of Vancouver Island.

The undersigned hopes to report that the large majority of the Indians in this Agency are heathens; that no denomination appears to have operated among them—at least not with success—except the Roman Catholics, who claim to have 596...
out of a population of 2864 Indians. This denomination has also 2 Day Schools, namely at Oolah and Claquato. The number of children of school age on the West Coast appears to be 389.

The undersigned considers that it would be well before giving a definite answer to Mr. Baird's application that the Visiting Indian Superintendent for British Columbia be required to report upon the proposition.

A. Macdonald,
Deputy Chief, General of Indian Affairs.
I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant

The Honorable
The Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, ONT.

MEMORANDUM.

To Deputy Minister

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, 12th January 1892

With ref. to memo. under of this date I beg to report that the number of children of school age in the West Coast Agency is 387. There were two schools in operation on the 30th June last. These were at O'right & Claquatch and are conducted under the auspices of the R.C. Church. The attendance at the two schools is 36 with an average attendance of 21. The population of the Agency is 2864 of which 2268 is pagan & 596 R.C.

John McFee

Dear Sir,

I am instructed by the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, to make application to the Government for a grant to the Indian School at Alberni. The condition of the Mission is as follows:

1. The Mission property consists of sixteen acres of land.

2. There is a Girls School in which there are, at present, thirteen (13) children. The accommodation is not such as to make it possible to receive others who are seeking admission. It was hoped that, by this time, the building would have been enlarged or a new one erected, but the sickness and necessary withdrawal of our Missionary, the Rev. J. A. MacDonald, has disappointed us in that. In a short time, however, a successor will be on the ground, and the enlargement will be effected as soon as convenient. It is proposed to accommodate from 20 to 25 in the new building. Miss B. I. Johnston, who is Matron of the School, and seems admirably fitted for the work, reports that both parents and children take a hearty interest in the Home.

3. The Day School has varied in attendance on account of the practice of children going with their parents, on their fishing and sealing expeditions. There were, on the Roll, during the Second Quarter of 1892, 20, average attendance 12 1/2. Third Quarter (1892) average 17 3/5 (number on Roll not reported). Fourth Quarter on Roll 30, average 16 1/2. First Quarter, 1893, on the Roll 14, average 8 3/5. Last statement received, 19th Sept., reports 20 on the Roll, with the remark that the attendance is becoming more regular, but average not given.

A new School House has been built on the Mission property and taken possession of by the School on the 6th of Sept., which will no doubt, contribute to its success.

Miss Maggie Minnes who has charge, is, so far as we can learn, a competent and devoted teacher.

4. There are thus employed in the Mission, a Missionary, a Matron, a Teacher, and a Helper who looks after the property and cultivates the land, in the interests of the Mission, the children themselves being taught, as far as possible, to share in the work.

5. The original cost of the land, with old building upon it, was $2000.00. The School House has cost about $300 only, the Indians themselves doing the greater part of the work, along with Mr. McKee who is in the service of the Mission.

By having boxes, about inches square along the base-board of the walls, open at the ends or perforated at intervals, the vitiated air will enter it, and if this box is connected about its centre with the main chimney which comes up from the furnace & supplies the rooms with the fresh heated air by means of a pipe entering into it, a draught will be created which will keep drawing the vitiated air out of the boxes, and send it up the chimney.

one mile further off would have little effect in affording facilities for procuring liquor. Feb. 7, 1896

Dear Sir:

I received today from Mr. Swartout, our Agent at Alberni a communication addressed to him by Mr. Harry Guillod, in which is expressed your general approval of the plans for the proposed Home for Indian children at that place, and suggesting certain changes worthy of consideration. Mr. Swartout has himself sent a reply to Mr. Guillod, of which he has sent me a copy. I shall, however, take the liberty of addressing directly to the Department a fuller statement, and without waiting for a meeting of our Committee, in order to expedite matters.

1. As to the number of children for which provision is made; We had intended, as you say, to provide for only twenty children. Upon further consideration, however, it was deemed advisable to expend so much money for the accommodation of a number not greater than we were providing for in the old building, although with very much crowding. It was also found that the Home has grown in popularity with the Indians, and that many who were formerly unwilling to send their children, are now seeking admission. Moreover, Mr. Swartout has commenced work at Uclalakht, and will thus gradually gain influence with these people, and induce, we hope, a number of them to send their children, so that we think before very long.
the full capacity of the new building will be required. The intention is to leave the old building where it is, and in some measure to utilize it in the same connection. Mr. Swartout thinks that much good would be accomplished if industrial work were begun, some of the children showing special aptitudes, which he would like to cultivate. There is evidently a large and opening field for usefulness, which we would like to develop to the best of our ability.

2. As to the breathing space of the dormitories. I have submitted to our architect, Mr. Gordon, your suggestion, and he informs me that the Ontario Statute requires two hundred and fifty cubic feet per child in our Day Schools, and that in these dormitories for forty children there are four hundred cubic feet each child, or if fifty were received that there would still be three hundred and thirty cubic feet for each, which he considers sufficient space.

3. The third point, as to ventilation, I have also submitted your proposal as to having boxing along the base board of the walls. He says that his intention was that the ventilation should be by registers in the chimneys,- inasmuch as there was one in connection with each dormitory. The method proposed by you, he says, is not much now in use, inasmuch as its advantages are over balanced by the disadvantage of leaving spaces in which
Toronto,

dust and vermin accumulate, as well as producing draughts near the floor. However, he says, that if the Department has a decided preference for that method of ventilation that it can be easily and inexpensively adopted. He believes that registers in the chimneys, not too near the ceiling, will both make an escape for foul air, and at the same time, not cause the warm air to pass out of the room, as it would if nearer the ceiling.

4. You object to what is called the "man's room" on the ground floor, and say that the presence of a man at all in the girls' building is regarded as objectionable. We on the other hand thought it so desirable that there should a trustworthy man about a place where there are so many women and children, that we made a special effort to provide that room. There are sixteen acres of land, which are cultivated in the interests of the Home, and Mr. McKee, who is at present employed, is an elderly man of special faithfulness and general usefulness, that we feel ourselves fortunate in having his services, and as well as giving a sense of security to the ladies employed in connection with the Mission. If however, the Department strongly objects to his occupancy of the room assigned to him in the new building, we, no doubt, can arrange otherwise. It would be necessary to have somebody on the ground capable of providing wood, and rendering such other ser-
vices as a man only can render.

5. There is no class room provided for in the Home, inasmuch as we have already a School House built upon the property, in which the children are instructed,- that School House was erected only a year ago, and as I understand, is very satisfactory.

6. As to the bath room in the attic, as well as the first floor, we also considered that, and decided against it, for the reason that it was supposed better not to indulge that class of children with too many of the modern conveniences. Our Matron stated that the children were very fond of bathing in the river,- that even when there were several inches of snow upon the ground, they delighted to go out bathing. She fears that their taste for that practise, which she regards as a healthful one, might be destroyed if too much accommodation were provided in the Home,- she, of course, exercises prudence as to allowing the weaker children, or any of them, to such exposure as might be hurtful. The ladies of the W. F. M. S., to whom the plans were submitted, also expressed the same view. Hence the decision arrived at. I have no doubt, however, that the Committee would be prepared to re-consider that decision if you still adhere to your suggestion.

7. The only other question to which attention has been drawn is the necessity of having the $1500.00 grant expended by the 30th., June. I hope that will be done, for we are anxious, as
quickly as possible, to get the extra accommodation. Mr. Swertout will use his best endeavors to that end. The matter was delayed by sickness on the part of agents and architects, etc., considerably beyond the date at which we hoped to have had the building under way. We shall do our best to fulfill the requirements of the Government. At the same time, I am sure, we may anticipate generous consideration at the hands of the Government, as to the question of time, should we be unable for any cause beyond our control, to complete the building within the stated period.

I need not say that there is no intention on the part of the Committee to call upon the Department for the expenditure in the erection of the building, of anything more than the sum named.

Again thanking you for your kindly and generous interest in the work,

I remain, very truly yours,

A letter has been received from the Principal of Alberni Indian Boarding School complaining that the cost of the electric current used for lighting this institution is too high and asking that consideration be given to the installing of a generating plant at the school. The building is now lighted from current furnished by the city of Alberni and the yearly cost at the rate of 15 cents per kilowatt hour amounts to approximately $280.00 per year. In his letter the Principal states that this yearly outlay for light would soon pay for a plant at the school.

With reference to this matter, I beg to say that the cost of operating an electric lighting plant if installed at the school, taking into consideration the yearly depreciation in the storage batteries, would amount to more than what is now being paid by the school for electric current, and I cannot recommend the installing of a lighting plant.

There is a point, however, regarding the current furnished the school, which might be given serious consideration. The city turns off the current during the day time and as the school is depending on this electric current for the operating of their laundry machinery, it is necessary for them to do most of the laundry work at night. To overcome this difficulty, a 3 H.P. Gasoline engine could be installed to operate the laundry machinery.

The cost of a 3 type Fairbanks-Morse 3 H.P. Gas. engine would be approximately $175.00, and I beg to recommend that Mr. Currie be authorized to purchase and have same installed.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 16th ultimo, referring to the question of the installation of two steel fire escapes at the Alberni Indian Boarding School from the top floor to the balconies on the second floor, I beg to say that as the outcome of a conference with Principal Currie and Indian Agent Cox on this matter it has now been suggested that brass poles should take the place of the ladders and I would recommend that this substitution be made, for if ladders are installed they would interfere with the closing of the balconies by wire netting already provided to prevent access by the boys to the balcony adjoining the girls' dormitory.

It appears to me that the simpler thing to do would be to have these brass poles erected from the ceiling of the top storey through the floor down to the floor of the dormitory immediately below on the second floor in a position near enough to the door leading to the balcony where the other poles are erected. By adopting this method the cost would, no doubt, be considerably less.

Please let me hear from you in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

W. E. Ditchburn,
Chief Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Dr. Edmison:

Please find enclosed some draft plans with accompanying explanation and estimated cost, sent me by Mr. Currie of Alberni, who asks that they may be forwarded to Ottawa. He also expresses the hope that they will go endorsed by you and the W. M. S.

The recreation hall is needed and was, I think, recommended by Drs. Wilson and Clay in the report they sent you some time ago, following their visit to Alberni.

The present rooms are not adequate, nor are they suitable as recreation rooms. They are in the basement, and are suitable places for the children to gather in and tidy up before going into the dining and class rooms. Even if they were suitable for recreation purposes, they would not give proper accommodation to more than half the present pupilage.

I sent these papers all down to Mrs. Clark, in order that she might consult with you. You were out of town at the time, and now Mrs. Clark has been ordered to bed for three weeks absolute rest. So the matter has been returned to me to place before you. Mrs. Clark and I feel there is need for this recreation hall, but we regret that the request did not come in earlier, so as to be included in the Gov't estimates for the fiscal year.

The sum, however, is small, and Mr. Currie is prepared to assume half of it, so possibly it might be considered as an emergency and secured in that way. I would like to have spoken with you on the matter, but that would cause further delay as I do not return to the city until Sept. 11th.

When you send this on to Ottawa, will you, at the same time, kindly draw attention to the absolute necessity of making provision for baths and toilets on the third floor at Alberni, now that they are having to use it for dormitory purposes.

I spoke of this to Mr. Ditchburn when I met him in Victoria, and saw that he was not enthusiastic about the expenditure. Mr. Currie, in his letter, says - "In the matter of bath and toilet accommodation on the upper floor, I took this up with Mr. Ditchburn. He would not sanction the expenditure, but referred the matter to Ottawa. I have had no word since."
The water pipes are laid to that floor, but there are no fittings. I would not consider the pressing of this matter in any way unreasonable. It is a necessity. Moreover, if this school is to have a male teacher, other changes should be made in the matter of staff room and toilet arrangements.

The present plan provides for a female staff only - apart, of course from the principal, and present arrangements will not be suitable when there is a mixed staff. If there are any points in connection with either of these matters on which I could give you further information, my address until Sept. 8th, will be Ipperwash Beach, Ravenswood P.O., Ontario. After Sept. 11th, I expect to be in Toronto, again.

Yours sincerely,

Signed: (Mrs. H. R. & Helen W. Horne,
Ass't Sec. for Indian Work.)

The Department of Indian Affairs,

Hon. Sirs:

At the present time we have 90 pupils enrolled, 48 boys and 42 girls. This number is ready to grow just as soon as this school is ready to open her doors to new pupils. From thirty to fifty pupils might readily be obtained right now, were we open to receive them. I only mention this here to indicate to you that this school is bound to grow, and so the thing I am at this time approaching you for is not for the present only, but is a part of the necessary equipment, the need of which will, as time goes on, be felt more and more.

There are two play rooms in our school, one for boys, one for girls. The size of the said play rooms is 21 x 33 feet. I might here draw your attention to the need of play rooms here on the West Coast of Vancouver Island, more perhaps than any other place in the whole Dominion. For days at a time, (I might say weeks and be literally true) it never stops raining at certain periods of the year. At such periods the pupils out of Class Room hours, have no place to go but to the said play rooms, where they are so crowded that they cannot play. It is bad for their health and for their morals. It is little short of criminal to continue or to try to put in another winter (the wet season) as we now are, with our increased enrollment. It was bad last winter, but so many new pupils makes it imperative that the matter be no longer delayed, but that steps be taken to remedy the situation at once before the wet season starts. Our climate is the finest in the world and all the play hours are spent out of doors.

After much mature consideration, I have come to the conclusion that to meet the situation a building at least 80 by 36 feet with 14 foot walls, suitable for such games as Basket Ball and for Gymnasium, is what we require. This building does not necessarily need be warm or expensive, but on account of its size it is bound to run into quite an item. For the time being, I would like to try it with an earth floor. If the earth floor proves unsatisfactory, I would make provision while building so that Joists and floor may be easily be added later.

I am submitting for your approval a plan with estimates of the said play room. This is a proposition rather larger than I am able to finance at the present time, unsided, but to assure its immediate construction, I am ready to sacrifice in some other quarter and will agree to meet half the cost. Or what is perhaps more definite, if the Indian Department will contribute $600.00, I will undertake to erect such a building, in every way, neat, strong and satisfactory.

As this is a matter urgent I will be pleased to receive your early approval of the proposition. Your cheque for the six hundred after the completion to the satisfaction of your Indian Agent.

Yours faithfully,

Sir:

Sir:

I have the honour to bring to the notice of the Department of Indian Affairs, the need of repairs to the plumbing system at the Alberni Indian Residential School, and respectfully request that this matter be given early consideration. I requested Mr. Herbertson, a plumber, to examine the system and if possible to make an estimate of the probable cost to put the system in good order; a copy of Mr. Herbertson's letter is attached hereto.

I also found the hose supplied for use for fire protection, is worn out and should be replaced as early as possible; the hose on hand is canvas, 2", and has been in use about 5 years; it leaks badly in many places under easy pressure, and would undoubtedly burst if subject to a full head of pressure in the event of a fire. I would further respectfully suggest that the hose supplied to replace that wornout, should be 1½", and that the necessary reducers be fitted to the hydrants at which this hose is used, my reasons for the suggestion are, The hydrants are 2", and a far better head of pressure is obtained when a smaller diameter hose is used, further the city has on hand hose that could be used in connection with 1½" fittings, but has no hose or connections to match that now in use at the Alberni School, so that in the event of a serious fire at that institution, it is now dependant entirely on its own resources, but, if supplied with hose matching that in use by the city fire brigade, outside appliances could be used in the event of a serious fire.

I made enquiries of the Fire Chiefs, as to the efficiency of the 1½" hose and they strongly recommend it with 2" hydrants.

1½" Insurance Mill brand hose, 250 feet would cost $90.00, Nozzle, $1.50, 2 reducers for hydrants from 2" to 1½", $2.50, each, 5 sets of couplings, attached to 5 fifty foot lengths of hose, $14.00. The probable approximate cost will be under one hundred fifteen dollars, including express or freight.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Edward E. Short

Rearrangement of Staff accommodation, with addition of necessary bathroom, etc.

Half the cost of Recreation Hall.

The erection of a Recreation Hall at Alberni is in line with recommendations made to us in a report by our Home Mission Superintendent for B.C., and a representative of Victoria Presbytery, after visiting Alberni School in company with Mr. Ditchburn, Inspector of Indian Agencies.

They strongly advised the appointment of a male assistant for the Principal, to help particularly with the boys, and recommended the erection of a recreation hall. We heartily concurred in this. The B.C. climate demands for considerable periods, indoor recreation rooms. Those provided in the Alberni School are in the basement, and are too small for the number of pupils now in attendance. The need is particularly marked on the boys' side. The sewing room in some measure relieves the difficulty on the girls' side.

Plans were submitted to the Department during the past summer; the estimated cost was small, and the Principal undertook to meet half. It was urgent that the building should be ready before the bad weather set in this fall.

The Principal is meeting half the cost, and we are confidently hoping that the Department will make good the other half as requested in the explanations which accompanied the plans now in the hands of the Department.

The request for rearranged Staff accommodation, with additional Staff bathroom, grows out of the report above referred to, followed also by a similar request from the Department re the appointment of a male assistant for the Principal. We have endeavored to comply with this request, but as can be readily seen, the introduction of increased male staff to a building arranged with a view to a female staff only, means rearrangement of rooms, and consequent additional bathroom accommodation. Representations regarding this requirement are already in the possession of the Department.

Dear Mr. Ditchburn,

I have at last got quotations on the plumbing fixtures required before the top Dormitory of our School can be put into use.

What I require is one toilet on the second floor, on the girls side of the school. (The floors are -- Basement, Ground Floor, First Floor, Second Floor.) For this toilet I propose to have one corner (North West) partitioned off 4 x 4 feet, this taken in one window, see the photo enclosed. The soil pipe from this toilet will go through the wall and run down the outside of the building, as indicated by red line on Photo, and connect with a waste dead end now there. Water to supply this Toilet for flushing purposes is now in this Dormitory and can easily be connected up. The only carpenter work in connection with this is 3 feet of partition 8 feet high, and one door.

On the Boys side of the school one toilet is required for the boys. One toilet for the Staff, A Staff Bath Tub, and a wash bowl. I propose to install the whole lot, in the small room taken off the Dormitory on the second floor at the time the school was built, for a disinfecting room. This Disinfecting room is directly over the boys wash room on the first floor. The soil pipe from the above fixtures will come through the floor and be suspended to the ceiling in the boys wash room, cross this room, run down the wall, exposed, again going through the floor to the hall of the ground floor, crossing said hall suspended to ceiling, passing through hall wall, into hall that runs to the laundry, then down to connect with soil pipe passing, at present, through the groceries store room or the basement floor. This soil pipe at present is in use in connection with the bath room fixtures in the Boys Infirmary. The Carpenter work necessary is as I have indicated on the rough sketch enclosed. And a window in the roof both for light and ventilation. At present this disinfecting room is dark.

I am enclosing you the three tenders I have received for this work, together with my remarks to each. The first tender is Thacker and Holt, Victoria, for $530.00 the school to furnish accommodation for their mechanic, freight fixtures from station to school and in conversation with me said that it would not pay to take a carpenter from Victoria to Alberni but for me to add to their tender what I considered the cost of the Carpenter work and material would amount to. My estimate for this, and what I would agree to have it done for is one hundred dollars. So really for the complete work Thacker and Holts tender is $630.00

The second tender is that of R.W.Evans, Alberni, for the complete work at $622.00. This is the tender that were I to let the contract would accept.

The third tender is in two parts, I might say three parts. The first part of this tender is from the Port Alberni Hardware store and is for the fixtures only $275.00. The second part of the tender is from H.E. Neale, to do the installation, supply soil pipe and fixtures at $462.50. The third part of this is the Carpenter work, you see Mr. Neal says he has not figured on that at all. So I take it that he wants us to
provide the carpenter to do this work. In such a case I think again one hundred dollars should be added to this contract price. So the three fixtures, Alberni Hardware Co., $275.00; Labor, Pipe, fittings H.E. Reale $462.00; Carpenter work added $100.00.

Total $837.00

In your letter you told me to consult Mr. A.W. Neill member for Comox-Alberni, as to who should be asked to tender. The parties that he wished to have a chance to tender was the parties sending in the third and highest tender. I called Mr. Neill up and informed him the prices quoted and he said in view of the much lower tender of Mr. Evans they could scarcely expect their tender to be considered.

Trusting this is sufficiently full information and that the work may be got under way just as soon as possible.

Yours faithfully,

H.B. Currie

Dear Sir:

Re Plumbing, Indian School Alberni.

We have visited the above school and made a careful examination of the plumbing and heating, the writer has not found any serious defects in the job. What matters are to attend to are as follows:

The supply of water seems to have a certain amount of grit washing through which has cut the seats of some of the valves and taps, destroying the washers; about 20 taps will require to have the seats reground and about 50 taps to be rewashed. Seventeen of these taps are in the Laundry. Four compression taps in the public lavatory have the handles broken off and will need renewal. Two lavatory basins have come loose from the wall and will need to be reset; one toilet bowl is choked by something becoming permanently lodged in the earthenware bowl and will need to be renewed; one Toilet Bowl is cracked and will need renewal. There are six Toilet Tanks out of order; one of these will have to be renewed, the others wanting certain parts and all want new rubber flush valves and ball cock washers.

The supply to the Slop Sink is choked in the wall and needs to be cut out and cleared. There are two Toilet Seats broken and will have to be replaced; new stoppers for twelve wash basins and four baths are required. The Bath in the girls Lavatory on ground floor is disconnected and the waste in the concrete floor choked; a portion of the floor will have to be taken up, the pipe cleared and repaired and the bath replaced, the main waste valve on the washing machine is broken and needs repairs.

The estimated cost of the above work will amount to approximately $225.00, and we hereby guarantee to do the work at this figure.

Awaiting your further esteemed orders.

Yours truly,

Thacker & Holt Per (Sgd.) Wm. Thacker

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 4th instant referring to the report from Mr. Agent Frost, of the West Coast Agency, that the plumbing system at the Alberni Indian School was in need of considerable repair, I beg to inform you that recently Mr. Wm. Holt, of the firm of Thacker and Holt, Victoria, (who installed the plumbing system at this School) informed me that he had to go up to Alberni on business, and, as he was conversant with the system at the School, I asked him to look over the condition of the plumbing and give the Department a report on what was necessary and the price for putting the same in good condition.

To-day I have received a report from Messrs. Thacker and Holt on what is considered to be necessary and offering a price of $225.00 to do the work. A copy of this report is attached hereto for your information.

The wearing out of the valves and washers in the taps is no doubt due to the fact that considerable sediment got into the water main, where it broke on two occasions a few years ago. It would appear to me that the blame of this work necessary at this time is due to either carelessness or willful destruction on the part of the pupils owing to lack of proper oversight by the authorities at the School, for it is remarkable to say the least, that whereas the plumbing system at the Kuper Island School put in by Messrs. Thacker and Holt now nearly fourteen years ago, is to-day in splendid condition, but the system at the Alberni School is, after a much less time, in the condition reported.

As the plumber Robert Herbertson, of Port Alberni, does not appear to be in a position to give a figure for the work, I would recommend that the offer of Messrs. Thacker and Holt be accepted.

With regard to the 250 feet of 1½" hose, couplings, nozzle and reducers which you requested me to purchase, I beg to say that these were ordered from the Dominion Rubber System (Pacific) Limited a week or so ago, and voucher and abstract of tender have been forwarded to the Department.

Ottawa, March 27th, 1926.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, relative to the starting of a manual training class at the Alberni Indian Residential School and the moving of the old classroom to another site. The sketch plan of the present lay out of the grounds and buildings, as well as the photo of the old classroom building, was also received.

In reply I beg to say that the Department has not contemplated the question of the moving of this old building to another site. You may, therefore, arrange to have the roof repaired and any painting required carried out. It is noted that you have the material for the purpose on hand. Any labour required for the purpose should be performed without any expense to the Department.

We regret that we have no funds to provide for the expense in supplying any equipment required for manual training purposes or for the payment of the services of a teacher. If, however, you are able to arrange for the carrying on of this activity, and the supplying of a moderate equipment for the purpose, the Department will be pleased if you will commence this work for the benefit of the senior pupils.

The photo of the old classroom is returned herewith as requested.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. H. E. Corrie,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Alberni, B.C.
I desire the Indian Department to start a manual training centre at Alberni Indian Boarding School as soon as convenient. Our S.S. teacher Mr. Gee Johnson has manual training qualifications. We only pay Mr. Johnson $900.00 per year. And he is a man who can command more. As I understand the Department pay about $500 per lesson to the Manual teachers. It would add about $200.00 more per year to Mr. Johnson's salary. Add be more of inducement for him to stay.

We have a very good building that might be used for this purpose with very little expenditure. (Our old Class Room.) I understand this matter has been already before the Department for their consideration. And further that a recommendation has been made to move the Old Class Room to another location. It is this latter that I object to. My reasons for objecting are:

1. That we need this building as it is. Not so much for the upper portion that will be used as a Manual Training Work room. But this building is erected on a splendid Concrete wall and has a concrete floor. It is next to indispensable for the storage of roots. We have no other place where they might be kept. And keep them we must, and if this building is removed another will have to be provided for the same purpose.

I understand the special idea in moving the Old Class Room from a scenic standpoint. From such a standpoint then the Teachers Cottage erected in 1925 should not have been erected at its present site. And further the new proposed site for the Old Class Room, from a scenic standpoint, is even more objectionable than where it now is. The proposed new site is on the North West corner of the Girls play ground, this is a menace to the safety of the girls. To bring the boys right where the girls are all the time, where the Old Class Room is now just to the East of the girls play ground but by erecting a fence from the old Class Room or the Teachers Cottage it is practically cut off from the girls play ground. In such case entrance may be obtained to the old Class Room from the Public Road or the North Boundary of the Property.

I am enclosing you a Plan of our present lay out. From this plan you will see there is a roadway right around the girls play ground. While I object to the moving of the Old Class Room, yet if it is your idea that it should be moved then I propose that at least it be moved say 80 or 100 feet further West than is now proposed. This will take it across the road and out of the girls play ground altogether.

I would like you to give careful consideration to the rough sketch I am sending before deciding this matter.

The Old Class Room does need a new Roof and paint both of which I purchased last summer, and would have had them on only this matter of the Removal of the School came up and was delayed doing the work till the matter was settled. I sincerely believe my proposals are the ones that should prevail, from a practical standpoint.

Yours faithfully,

H.B. Currie

Dear Sir:

Re: Indian Education

In connection with my report on the Estimates for the Fiscal Year 1927-28, I dealt only with the item for General Administration, leaving out anything pertaining to Indian Education.

At the Alberni school the Principal is desirous of having a manual training department. It is proposed that the old classroom building should be moved close to the main school and fitted out for manual training purposes, the cost of which will be approximately $600.00 to cover the cost of removing present building, equipment, all tools and working materials.

I am attaching hereto copies of correspondence from Indian Agent Frost on this subject. As these came to hand after the Estimates for 1926-27 had been forwarded to Ottawa, I decided to hold the matter off until dealing with those for 1927-28.

(Sgd.) W. E. DITCHBURN,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.
Sir:

I have the honour to bring to your attention the question of Manual Training for boy pupils of the Alberni Indian Residential School, and would like to know if you think the expenditure necessary for that purpose would be justified.

The training of boy pupils is at present confined entirely to farming, and that, only in a limited way, as the facilities of the school does not admit of a thorough training. The boys are taught dairying, hog and poultry raising, and the cultivation of such ordinary farm crops as are suitable for use at the school and on the school farm, but, as farming is the least likely industry to be practiced by the boys after leaving school, I think other lines of training could be taught that would be of more practical benefit in fitting the boys to earn a livelihood.

The facilities existing at the school in favour of this project, are, the building previously used as a classroom would be suitable, if moved and sills put under it, I estimate the cost of moving the building $100.00, the cost of material for sills $25.00. A fully qualified Manual Training instructor is available whose services could, I think be secured for $5.00 per week for two lessons, or say $200.00 per year.

The cost of tools I estimate at about $300.00, and material for interior fitting of the building for training purposes, $25.00, the work itself could be done by the pupils as part of their training.

If you consider this suggestion worth consideration, I could get expert estimates as to cost of moving the building, and tools, if you so direct.

I may say that I discussed this matter with Mr. Cairns on his recent visit and he expressed himself as in favour of the suggestion.

Your obedient servant,

"Edward E. Frost".

W.E. Ditchburn, Esq.,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 16th instant referring to the matter of giving manual training instruction to the pupils of the Alberni Residential School, and in reply I beg to say that I am perfectly in accord with your remarks contained therein.

In various places throughout the Province of British Columbia, the Department has already in operation a system such as the one to which you refer, that is by employing a qualified manual training instructor of the district for this purpose. This instructor is generally connected with some of the white public schools.

I, therefore, would be glad if you would go further into this matter, and get an estimate on the cost of having the buildings and the tools. You should also give particulars as to who the qualified manual training instructor is to whom you refer. On receipt of this information from you, I will then take up the matter with the Department and, if possible, have the scheme put through, for I am fully impressed with the fact that it is something of this character that the Indian boys of the West Coast should be taught, as they are not now, and never will be able to do anything very much in the way of farming, consequently any extensive instruction along this line will be of no practical value to them.

Your obedient servant,
"W.H.Ditchburn",

"The other thing I need is more milk. There is only five miserable milk cows here and two good cows will give me more milk than the five. It is easy to pick up cheap miserable stuff like what is now here. But it is not much of a training to boys to handle such stuff. I know from actual experience at Alberni that as soon as good cows came on the place the interest of the boys increased 100%. At Alberni I built up the very best herd of dual purpose Pure Bred Shorthorns in the Province. Just look up Report No. 18 of Pure Bred Dairy Cattle of the Dom. Government. There you will see in the 4 year old Shorthorn Section my cow "Augusta Glad Eyes" led all Canada in her class, and Roan Marie in the Mature Class occupied 4th place in Canada. In leaving Alberni, nothing grieved me so much as leaving them behind. I left over 30 head at Alberni that any one might envy, and that number is more than the present Principal needs, or can handle to advantage. "I must have cows here after the summer vacation, my resources will only permit me to secure "just cows". I believe I can buy four cows or heifers from Alberni School for $600.00 and pay the transportation. Will you allow me a grant of $600.00 for this purpose?"

Reverend Sir:

I am directed to acknowledge your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to an assembly hall at the Alberni Indian Residential School. Dear Sir:

I beg to advise you that the new barn at the Alberni Indian Residential School is in need of some repairs to doors. This damage has, in my opinion, been contributed to by their failure to open freely, caused by the pulling out of plumb of the barn, caused by the weight of the manure conveyer which is attached to the upper portion of that structure and supported, originally, only by guys or stays which are fixed to the higher portion of upper structure. Sir:

In accordance with instructions contained in your No. 15/9097, of 28th ultimo, re need of assembly hall or farmer's cottage for Alberni Indian Residential School.

I beg to report that I have carefully looked into this matter and in my opinion, which is concurred in by the new Principal, Rev. F.B. Pitts, there is more need of a cottage for the farming instructor than there is for an assembly hall at that school. The need of the assembly hall is not apparent and the purpose of such a building is not clear to me, while the need of farmer's cottage is apparent. The present occupant of that position has held it for the past two years and during that time has only been able to be with his family for a few days on three occasions during the school holidays. He has tried to obtain housing accommodation for his family in Alberni but has failed to do so as there are no vacant houses in this vicinity.

There is at present a building which was erected in 1925 and is being used as a play and games room for the boys during the winter and in bad weather. It is approximately seventeen feet long by thirty-five feet wide. It is constructed of rough lumber on a concrete foundation but it is not floored. If funds are available the building might be floored, windows repaired and screened and whatever gymnastic appliances deemed necessary installed if so desired. If you desire I will get an estimate of the approximate cost of a concrete or lumber floor for this building. I do not think a concrete floor is best suitable for a playroom or gym. The building is already fitted for electric light. The estimated cost of any kind of floor you prefer and the cost of window repairs and screening will be obtained and submitted at your instruction.

I may say that a suitable site for a cottage is available, less a hundred yards from the school in close proximity to farm buildings, just outside the school enclosure.

Your further instructions if any awaited.

Mr. Henion has followed up by visits to the building a report received at Head Office that the heating system at the above building was not giving satisfaction.

Mr. Henion found that the local authorities called in Messrs. R. Robertson & Sons, Heating Contractors at Fort Alberni, to go over the system, in an endeavour to locate the trouble, and correct same.

The Contractors were not familiar with this work or type of system, and did not do the original installation. They wrote to the C.A. Dunham Co., asking for full particulars regarding the job. Upon receipt of this arrangements were made to have Mr. Henion make an inspection.

It was found three or four radiators would at times fail to heat up, and also a part of system farthest removed from the boiler room appeared somewhat sluggish. In order to overcome this condition the boiler pressure was raised to 5 to 8 lbs.

Some of the connections will need to be changed to give proper grading to the spring pipe to the radiators. This matter was taken up by Mr. Henion with Mr. Robertson, and instructions given how to accomplish the necessary change.

The reason that the system farthest removed from the boiler room does not heat is due to carrying excessive pressure on the type of system installed. The system as installed is a gravity system of steam heating with the air relieved from the return piping through a Dunham Air Eliminator. When pressures over one above 8 ozs. are carried on the system the Eliminator seals the system, due to the water rising in the stand pipe and causing the float to close the valve on the Eliminator and thus preventing air from leaving the system. The continued carrying of high pressure above 8 ozs. makes the system practically a sealed system, and steam cannot find enter the radiation due to the fact that air cannot find its way out of the return piping.

This condition noted above is due to the manner of firing and the fuel used, which is wood, which causes the steam pressure on the boiler to build up before the radiation throughout the system is filled with steam, therefore the radiators at the end of the system or mains, are the ones that suffer by lack of steam.

We would recommend that a No. 10 Dunham Return Trap be installed which will permit the pressure on the boiler to be carried at any time from 1 to 10 lbs., and the air would be vented out of the return mains through an eliminator, and the water returned to the boiler by the return trap.

It is almost impossible to maintain a steady condition of pressure on the boiler when burning wood as fuel, and a gravity steam heating system using only an air eliminator for venting the air from system will freeze.
time to time give trouble as is being experienced on this system, but with
the installation of a Dunham Return trap air will have a free vent from
the return piping regardless of pressure carried on the boiler.

We would further recommend that all of the traps be gone over and
cleaned. That is the covers and discs taken off, and any foreign matter
within the trap bodies removed.

There appears to be evidence of having carried too high a water
line on the boiler, and we believe that the manufacturers of the boiler
should be communicated with and the height of the water line for the boiler
ascertained, and the operator instructed to carry the water line at
the level stipulated by the manufacturer.

The Damper Regulator which is now connected to the boiler, should
be connected to the balanced Check Damper on the smoke pipe, and to the
draft damper on front of the boiler, so that these can work together with
the damper regulator, and assist in maintaining a steady pressure on
the boiler.

We would recommend that a compound gauge be installed on the
boiler, since the gauge now on the boiler has been found defective
and causing trouble in the past.

The Air Line Valves now installed on the end of steam mains to
be replaced with No. 1 Dunham Radiator traps to give a freer venting
of air from the steam pipes into the return piping.

Some of the return piping in the boiler room is badly packed,
and this will need to be straightened up.

All of the matters covered in this report were discussed with
the Contractors called in on the job, and with the above recommendations
followed out this system should operate satisfactorily.

Respectfully submitted,

C. A. MUNN & CO., LTD.
Engineering Department,

H. W. Shears, Engr.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit herewith a report from the manual training Instructor to the classes at the Alberni Indian Residential School for your information.

The report covers the period from commencement of instruction, in January to the closing of the school for the summer holidays, on June 30th, 1927, 6 months.

The boys have proved themselves apt and willing pupils, and their ability to grasp the lessons presented to them is very marked, and I feel confident that the drawing of plans and constructing of models to scale will prove of great benefit to the boys of this Agency as the most important and almost sole means of livelihood for the Indians of the West Coast is fishing and the repairing of the craft and plant buildings in which they are employed, and I hope in due time it will lead to the construction of a better type of dwelling on Indian Reserves.

In conclusion I beg to state that the estimated cost of manual training at the Alberni school for the current school year, to end of June 1928, will be approximately, $300.00, which will include Instructor's salary, tools if any are needed and material for the class to work with.

Your obedient servant,

Edward E. Frost

Sir,

I beg to submit the following report on manual training at the Indian Residential School, Alberni, B.C., for the year ending June 30th, 1927.

During the year, 85 classes were held, showing a total instruction period of 209½ hours. This total was divided among 3 classes. The number of boys receiving instruction was 26, of which 17 are expected to return after the holidays.

The type of instruction given has been almost identical with that given in the public schools of this Province, each model being accompanied by a working drawing. The models have been small combining utility with economy, requiring simple tool operation. The course so far has been fairly rigid—few alternative problems being allowed, thus each class has faced the same projects and has tackled the same problems. Friendly competition and discussion have been encouraged.

For the future I feel that for the bigger boys a different course should be arranged, one more suited to the needs of an Indian boy who will soon be earning his living on a fishing boat. Household utensils or simple furniture will be undertaken as individual projects, while for those boys more apt or more willing, special instruction in boat building will be given, in this way the training will provide the boy with a working knowledge of the tools and methods used in the construction of wooden articles used every day.

While the various metals offer splendid mediums for manual training I think that too much should not be attempted at this stage. Therefore I propose to adhere closely to wood, paying special attention to lumber which is produced locally. When the time is ripe for the introduction of more technical education in Indian schools the boys will prove themselves to be apt and willing students of all branches of handicraft.

In conclusion I wish to acknowledge with thanks the valuable advice, blueprints and books given by Mr. John Kyle, Organizer of Technical Education. I also wish to thank you, Sir, for your kindly consideration, assistance and hearty co-operation, without which manual training could not have been so successfully commenced at this school.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

George Johnson, Instructor.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of May 16th (File No. 159-1-5) relative to a farmer's cottage at the Alberni Residential School, B.C., also an assembly hall, you enquire which of these buildings is the more necessary.

On receipt of your letter I at once wrote to Mrs. Clark, the representative of the Women's Missionary Society who looks after the Indian Work of which this Society has special supervision, and asked her to let me know which building they would rather have erected. I did not have a reply from her in regard to this matter until a few days ago when she gave me to understand that it is her judgment that the farmer's cottage is the more desirable. She seemed to be under the impression that it was already being erected. As to this you will of course have all information. They would be delighted if both buildings could be provided as soon as possible.

I am,

Asst. Gen. of Indian Affairs
Alberni, B.C.

Dear Sir,

In reply to yours of Oct 6th 27 to Principals of Indian Residential schools re fire protection and escapes. I beg to report for Alberni Residential school as follows:

1. Fire Alarm - There is no general fire alarm in the school - only small bells, similar to door bells in a private home. These are used by the children if they are sick or require to call a member of staff in the night. There should be a bell or alarm centrally located and sufficiently loud to alarm the whole school at once.
2. The only fire escapes except the stairs are brass rods, similar to those used by fire departments in fire halls. As the ceilings here are 12 ft high it makes about 16 ft from where a child takes hold of the rod to the floor below. If they hold too tightly they are likely to burn their hands and let go or if too loosely they are likely to drop to the floor below. Even these rods change from one room to another at each floor. This would likely cause confusion if there was smoke or danger.

I have taken Agent E.E. Reid and Inspector Gavin of Vancouver over the building and both concern with
I see in this report that the fire alarm and the means of exit are both adequate for the number of children and size of the building we have here.

3. Our hydrants, hose, and water pressure are good.

4. Our fire extinguishers are only 2 quart size and in these large rooms would not do the work. I would like to suggest that these be replaced at the earliest convenience with Booth & Coulter 2½ or 3 gal. extinguishers tested at 300-350 lbs.

5. Nearly all the doors in this building lock with a different key.
If these are necessarily locked at night and would cause delay and confusion in getting through the building I would therefore recommend that 12 fire axes with picks on the back be placed conveniently throughout the building so that they could be used to break down the doors or get at the source of the fire.

I would not like to take the responsibility of suggesting what kind of fire escape should be used or where it should be placed.

I would like to see the fire extinguishers and fire axes placed at our disposal at the earliest convenience.

Yours obediently,

F.E. Pitts

January 10, 1928.

Dear Mr. Hunter:

The Department has recently asked for a report on fire escape facilities at the government-owned Indian Residential School at Alberni, B.C. I have been unable to secure the opinion of any person competent in the matter, and I am writing to you to learn if it would be possible to have your local architect inspect the building and report concerning what additional fire escapes should be provided, with an estimate of the cost.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

J. B. Hunter, Esq., B.A.,
Deputy Minister,
Dept. of Public Works,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir:

I have the honour to refer to Department's letter dated Ottawa, November 28th, 1927, re fire escape equipment and appliances at Alberni Indian Residential School.

I beg to advise the Department that after making exhaustive enquiries I find that there is no competent authority in Alberni that can give a ruling and make the necessary recommendations together with the estimated cost of installing a satisfactory system. I therefore referred the matter to Mr Commissioner, W.E. Ditchburn, for his advice, and he has suggested that the Department be asked to request the Dominion Public Works Department to instruct its local architect to make the necessary investigation of the building and supply the information called for by the Department.

I respectfully submit Mr Commissioner, W.E. Ditchburn, a recommendation to the Department for consideration and request that I may be informed of its decision.

Your obedient servant

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

I have the honour to report for the information and consideration of the Department that the toilet system in both the girls and boys toilet on the lower floor at the Alberni Indian Residential School is in urgent need of overhaul and repair.

I beg to state that the system in the toilets complained of has been a constant source of trouble and expense, to my personal knowledge, during the past 4 years, about every 3 months and sometimes at shorter periods these toilets have needed a plumber's attention to put them in order, and as this has been a frequent drain on the school resources it is felt that the system should be improved so as to obviate the frequent need of expenditure on cleaning and repairs as well as to improve the sanitary conditions arising from defective toilets.

I therefore respectfully suggest for the consideration of the Department, the replacing of the present system by installing the Standard Automatic Syphon Education Range Toilet, 3 stalls in the girls division and 2 stalls with 35 inch urinal in the boys section. The approximate cost of the toilets suggested would be as under: 3 stall $275.00, 2 stall $220.00, 35 inch urinal $50.00. The above estimated costs include the toilets complete with fittings and installation, but does not include the cost of such concrete work as might be needed in floors or the erection of wood partitions, the latter I believe could be erected by the manual training class as part of their instruction, so that only the cost of the necessary lumber for same would be incurred.

An early intimation of the Department's views on the above matter is respectfully requested please as further expenditure on the repairs to the present system is urgent.

Re: Government Owned Indian Residential School - Alberni, B.C.

Dear Sir,-

As instructed by your letter of the 16th ultimo, file #87551 an inspection of the above named building has been made, and I now beg to report as follows:

The building is a three storey frame building with basement. Roof covered with rubberized felt roofing. The building is divided into two by a lath and plaster wall dividing the boys from the girls, and whatever method of fire escape is used it will have to accommodate both ends of the school.

The fire preventative service has been taken care of, to some extent by the installation of a number of large three and a half gallon chemical hand tanks and several smaller pyrene fire extinguishers placed at convenient points.

The stair wells are situated at each end of the building, and if a fire should occur in the basement or on the first floor, the occupants of the upper floors would be cut off as the fire and smoke would no doubt travel up the stair wells. There is a brass pole, from one floor to the other, after the fire hall style, but should a fire occur, this again, would cause a draft and the smoke and flames would travel up through these holes, and even if there were not smoke and flames to contend with, the smaller children could not possibly make use of these poles at any time without considerable danger to themselves.

There is no fire alarm system in the building. This should be rectified by the installation of an electric alarm system of songs to be placed at suitable positions on the various floors as shown on plan and served by a six volt storage battery, one battery to be kept in stock fully charged as a spare.

It was found that the heating of the building was carried on by the boys under the supervision of the Master, or of some person who has the necessary engineer's certificate. This system means that the boys do most of the firing, as on the occasion of the inspection, a large number of boys in the boiler room were found drying their clothes over a small box stove which was red hot and a menace to the building.

If wrought iron......
If wrought iron fire escapes were placed on the front wall in the recess above and at the sides of the main entrance steps, as marked on plan, it would take care of each of the floors.

The children on the different dormitories on the second floor could be mustered in the wash rooms (which have terrazzo floors) as there is an entrance to the wash rooms from each dormitory in each end of the buildings, and those on the third floor would have direct access to the fire escape.

Doorways should be cut in the walls on the second floor, where indicated on the plan, to give access to the staff from the staff rooms to the dormitories. In case of fire coming from below by way of the staircases, escape would be cut off for these people.

I therefore recommend that a wrought iron fire escape be erected to each part of the building as shown on sketch plan, at an approximate cost of $1475.00

Two doorways cut and doors put in complete at an approximate cost of $50.00

Complete system of songs and service break glass stations with storage batteries complete and located at points as shown on plan at an approximate cost of $220.00

Total cost $1745.00
Plus 10% $174.50
$1919.50

Please return plans of building.

Yours faithfully,

I may say,I have been repairing these roofs for several years past and only last season covered one piece of the laundry roof that had cracked for twenty feet or more as well as numerous small leaks,some of which are extremely difficult to find,I may also add that I had to renew several pieces of beaver board in the ceilings that had been destroyed by leaks.

Trusting that these suggestions will be of value to you.

I am Sir,
Yours truly,
(signed) Robert Milligan.

Dear Sirs:

At Alberni Indian School, please note that when your Architect Mr. Dawson of Victoria came to see the building before getting out the plans, I pointed out to him that the school had been erected with a view to keeping the boys and girls sides of the building absolutely separated on the top flats and that any fire-escape should keep this in view and also that as we were near the Reserve there should be no access from the ground to the dormitories. I also pointed out to him that there was one side of the front porch was the office and on the other side was the reception room and that these were the only front rooms we had in the building for use of staff and that these windows should not be blocked by the fire-escape.

Practical men and builders agreed with me that the fire-escape could have started from the same place had access through the same windows and been attached to the blank wall of the projections on either side of the porch and would have thus avoided all the difficulties I have referred to.

As it is erected the top balconies of the escape are connected along the roof, the second balconies are connected or are of easy access across the roof of the front porch and the balconies of the ground floor (that is above the basement) are of easy access from the floor of the front porch. The balconies of the ground floor are right in front of the office and reception room windows.

Since the fire escape is so easy of access from the ground and makes possible access from one side of the building to the other it becomes necessary to have these windows opening on the fire-escape securely locked, as I do not want to take the responsibility of fastening up the access to the fire-escape. I wish to ask your instructions as to what way those windows shall be secured to prevent any one from gaining access to the dormitories or store rooms in the night.

Again, just in front of each of the windows opening on the balconies there is a hole 3 feet 6 inches long by 15 inches high, level with the floor and opening to the well-hole of the steps. A child crawling out of the window and going a little too far or rolling over would drop down the steps clearing all ahead of him or else drop through the outside rail which is also 15 inches from the steps. There should be a second bar or some wire screening put on this rail to ensure that no such accident happens.

I sincerely hope you will have these things inspected and give instructions as to what should be done.

Yours sincerely,

(Ed) F.E. Pitts.
Sir,

I have the honour to advise the Department that the fire escape has been erected at the Alberni Indian Residential School, and I am enclosing herewith a copy of a letter from the Rev. F.B. Pitts, Principal of that school in which he wishes to bring to the notice of the Department some points in connection with the fire escape. The Rev. Principal's points are 4 in number and are:

1. The keeping of boys and girls separate,
2. Windows obscured by the fire escape,
3. Access to dormitories by means of fire escape,
4. Dangerous openings in the railing of the escape.

With reference to the fire escape and the Rev. Principal's remarks, I beg to state that in my opinion the escape is very staunchly constructed and in every particular complies with requirements called for by the fire protection regulations of the Province.

1. Keeping boys and girls separate. To prevent the access from one dormitory to another by the fire escape and over a portion of the roof, I beg to suggest that hinged screens be placed on the inside of the dormitory windows where necessary, that the screens be fastened with a padlock and that a fireman's axe be kept hanging on the wall immediately by the screen so that no time need be lost in effecting exit in case of fire.

2. Position of the escape. There can be no possible doubt but that the same escape could have been erected leading to the same exits without obscuring the window, s of either office or reception rooms, and that without any additional cost.

3. Access to dormitories from the ground by means of the escape. The hinged screens recommended for 2 will prevent this.

4. Dangerous openings in railing of the escape. To remedy this, I requested the Rev. Principal to have some heavy wire netting stretched over these and securely wired to the railing of the escape. Cost will be very little.

I beg to add that I was present when the attention of the Architect was drawn to the necessity of not obscuring the office and reception room windows, at the time the survey of the building was made for the drawing of plans for the escape.

As no plan was available either at the school or in this office, no opportunity was given to bring these points to the notice of the Department before the structure was erected, no plan of the structure has yet been seen here.

Dear sir:

Yours of the 12th inst ref painting of this school to hand.

You ask if in my opinion the painting of the whole building is absolutely necessary. In reply the same was erected and opened in December 1920. With the exception of the steps and porch floors no painting has been done on it since. For both appearance and economy I would say that the painting was very necessary, but of course paint is never absolutely necessary.

Replying to whether the work of putting on the paint could be done by the staff and older boys. The building is over 40 feet to the eaves, this requires the best of scaffolding and a man accustomed to working at 40 feet in the air—we could not do the scaffolding and I would not take the risk of young boys working at that height, nor have we anyone on our staff that who could do so. We are busy long days and all day with school and farm work and would have to hire extra help for any extra work. Our outlay for repairs, fencing and cleaning land has been heavy during the past year and so we cannot take on any extra expense just now.

Again, it does not seem to be economy to have an $80,000.00 dollar building painted by amateurs, and as holidays start soon we could not possibly finish the painting, along with harvesting etc before the wet weather begins in the fall.

We appreciate the willingness of the Department to furnish the paint but cannot accept it on these conditions.

Yours truly,

(F.E.) F.E. Pitts.

Mr. Agent Frost and the Principal have strongly urged the necessity of the exterior painting of the Alberni Indian Residential School building. The roof of the main building and the exterior walls require one coat of paint, also the steps, verandah, ceilings and floors. No funds have been specially provided; but the amount required - $755 - could be taken from our appropriation for Indian Education. I would recommend that authority be granted to have this painting carried out and will be pleased to have the necessary approval, also the name of the man who should be engaged as foreman in charge of the painting.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, with enclosed letters, and I might state that the construction of the fire escape is in accordance with the B.C. fire Marshall's specifications.

With reference to Mr. Pitts remarks that the fire escape could have been attached to the blank walls of the building, I might state that the cost of construction would have been half as much again, and almost impracticable to have put an escape from the dormer windows, which would have had to be brought at right angles across the valleys and along the roof, also at each side practically the same landing would have had to be put at the windows as at present to ensure using both windows for quick exit, and then carried along the blank wall and the same accessibility from the ground would be available. The present location is considered the best position.

Mr. Pitts remarks that the top balconies are connected is not true, and any persons attempting to get from one balcony to another are endangering their lives, as they would have to travel along the gutter of the building which is a very dangerous proceeding. I am aware that one boy did this during the erection of the fire escape, but the roof was covered with jacks and scaffolding for the use of the workmen.

Mr. Pitts objection to the stopping of light into rooms was taken into consideration and pointed out to him that it would make very little difference to the light.

The sashes and screens of all the windows leading to the fire escape should be hinged and bolted inside, a fire axe should also be hung up on each floor at a convenient point.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd) J.G. Brown,
Dist. Res. Architect.

I have the honour to submit to the Department a request by the Rev. F.E. Pitts, B.A., Principal of the Alberni Indian Residential School, for authority to re-appropriate the old class room of that school, which has been, during the past two years, used for Manual Training purposes, and use the same as an additional class room for part of Grades 1 and 2, and for the supply by the Department of the necessary equipment for that purpose; and further, to sanction the transfer of the Manual Training classes, equipment, and fixtures (except the electric lighting fixtures) to the basement of the same building, and the installing of electric lights in the latter room, for Manual Training use.

I respectfully recommend the above request to the Department for favourable consideration for the following reasons. There are 71 pupils in Grades 1 and 2, and I believe, insufficient air space as called for by regulations, in the junior classes' room when filled to its capacity, further, as a large portion of the pupils in this room are beginners, the class is too large for any one teacher to handle satisfactorily.

This request was held in abeyance until the visit of Mr. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools, in order that the matter might be thoroughly investigated by him and discussed with the Principal and myself, this having been done on 7th instant and received Mr. Cairns approval.

The transfer of the Manual Training classes and equipment to the basement of this building will cause no inconvenience to those classes as the basement room is larger than the floor above, it has airtight concrete walls and floor and heat heating facilities but will need electric lighting fixtures to be installed at an estimated cost of approximately $20.00.

The estimated cost of the equipment needed for the proposed additional classroom is approximately $500.50 including freight, and is compiled as follows: 15 desks size B, $180.00; 15 desks size C $172.50; 1 Teachers desk $25.00; 12 kindergarten chairs $21.00; Hyloplate 4' x 30' $35.00; 1 galvanised green liquid slating $6.50; 1 Union Jack $7.50; 1 hand bell $5.00; freight $30.00.

Total cost of equipping both rooms for the purposes stated, including electric light fittings for basement $520.50.

Requisition for the equipment needed is attached hereto.

Your obedient servant,
