Dear Sir;-

Enclosed herewith find a special requisition for desks &c to equip a third class-room in Alberni Residential School.

Our reasons for opening a third class-room are evident from our quarterly report. Since January 1st 1927, thirty-nine new pupils have entered the school, with the exception of two these have all been beginners who have had very little English, consequently our standards 1 and 2 have become crowded too much for one teacher and as these so much individual attention the teacher in the senior room cannot do justice to the older ones and take part of these standards 1 and 2.

We are asking, therefore, to move the Manual Training to the basement of the former school building and use the present Manual Training room for the Primary class and equip it for thirty beginners. The second teacher to take part of standard 1 and part of standard 2 and the senior teacher to take the others, this arrangement would seem to relieve the situation and give all a fair chance.

May I add that I have gone into these matters with you yourself and Mr Inspector Cairns and we all agreed that,

1. The basement of the separate class-room building was very suitable for Manual Training.

2. That the present Manual Training room is also suitable for a primary class-room.

3. That it is desirable and necessary to make the changes above asked for. We therefore sincerely hope that the Indian Department may grant to us the sanction and the equipment asked for.

Yours sincerely,

(signed) F.E.Pitts, Principal.

Indian Agent Frost is sending in a voucher for one day's pay for J. Taylor.

He borrowed this man from the Provincial Govt in an attempt to have the painting on the school done by day's work. Sir,

I have the honour to submit the attached claim presented by James Taylor for $4.50 for one day's time in connection with the painting of the Alberni Indian Residential School.

Explanation. Mr. A.J. Thomas, who was appointed foreman to superintend the work, reported to me that he could not get painters, and asked me to try and find one or two to help him out. I saw the Provincial Public Works Engineer and secured the loan of James Taylor, and Taylor was instructed by me in writing, with the approval of Mr. Thomas, to report at Alberni School not later than 8 a.m. on Monday August 27th for work. Taylor reported at the time and place named. Mr. Thomas arrived later and stated that he had failed to get any men to work with Taylor, and as it was useless for one man to commence the work and he, Thomas, could see no likelihood of getting men, he asked to be relieved of his appointment as foreman.

It was then too late for Taylor to return to his work with the P.W.D., as he had come in some 12 miles from a road camp. Taylor consequently lost a day's work with the P.W.D., hence the claim, which having due regard to the facts, is in my opinion, legal, and I respectfully recommend the payment of the same by the Department of Indian Affairs.

Your obedient servant,

Ed. E. Frost
Indian Agent.

Alberni, B.C.—November 22, 1928.

Dear sir:

Some five or six years ago, the Indian Department erected a hall for recreation purposes at this school. The size of the building is 80' by 36', stands on a cement foundation and is in good repair, except that it was never finished. The only floor is the natural soil on which it stands. In any dry weather this works up into dust and the children require a bath after a game of ball, or if the floor is sprinkled it becomes very slippery and muddy. It is very rough at all times and any amount of work at smoothing and levelling lasts for only a short time.

The necessity for such a playroom is self-evident to anyone who knows anything of this climate. From November to May 1st, the rains are exceedingly heavy and for three months of that time there are many days that it pours rain all day.

Therefore I want to appeal to the generosity of the Department of Indian Affairs to complete this playroom so that it may be suitable for both girls and boys to use at different times for basket-ball and other games.

The cost would be approximately as follows—

| Item                        | Cost   |
|-----------------------------|--------|
| 25 bags of cement @ $1.00 per bag | $25.00 |
| 120 joist (2 by 10 by 12 ft.) @ $20 per M | $52.00 |
| 500 ft. bridging (1 by 4) | $7.00 |
| 4500 ft. fir flooring | $112.50 |
| 2000 ft. " wainscoting" | $50.00 |
| Cartage of lumber | $25.00 |
| " gravel | $10.00 |
| Labor and nails | $125.00 |

Total—$406.50

We have now 100 children in the school and are badly in need of just such a playroom as this hall would afford if it were fitted up as above specified.

We sincerely hope that your Department may see fit to grant our request and carry out this work at an early date.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal.
